questions.prompt: What are the two main parts involved in creating websites according to web design principles?

options.text: Making the server and the database

feedback.short: Not quite\! Server and database are backend concerns, not web design fundamentals.
feedback.detailed: Web design focuses on the frontend (what users see). Servers and databases are backend technologies that handle data storage and business logic. The question asks about the two visual aspects of web design.
feedback.socraticHint: What two technologies control how a webpage looks and is organized?

options.text: Making the content (HTML) and making the layout (CSS)
Making the frontend and the backend

feedback.short: Not quite\! Frontend/backend is a broader architectural division.
feedback.detailed: While frontend and backend is a valid way to think about web development architecture, this question specifically asks about web design principles. Web design focuses on HTML (content structure) and CSS (visual styling).
feedback.socraticHint: Which two languages work together to create the visual appearance of a website?

options.text: Making the images and the text

feedback.short: Not quite\! Images and text are content types, not the technologies that create them.
feedback.detailed: Images and text are examples of content on a website. Web design principles are about the technologies (HTML and CSS) that structure and style all content, not just specific content types.
feedback.socraticHint: What are the two coding languages that web designers use to build websites?

questions.correctAnswerText: Making the content (HTML) and making the layout (CSS)

questions.prompt: According to the table comparing web versions, what makes Web 2.0 different from Web 1.0?

options.text: Web 2.0 is faster than Web 1.0

feedback.short: Not quite\! Speed improvements are technical, not the defining feature of Web 2.0.
feedback.detailed: While Web 2.0 sites may be faster due to improved technology, the fundamental difference is about user participation. Web 2.0 introduced interactivity where users could create and share content, not just consume it.
feedback.socraticHint: What can users do on Facebook or YouTube that they couldnt do on early 1990s websites?

options.text: Web 2.0 allows users to both read and write/interact, not just read-only
Web 2.0 uses better graphics than Web 1.0

feedback.short: Not quite\! Graphics quality is a technical detail, not the core distinction.
feedback.detailed: Better graphics are a result of improved technology, but they arent what defines Web 2.0. The key difference is user interaction - Web 2.0 allows users to create content, comment, and participate actively.
feedback.socraticHint: Think about social media - what makes it different from old static websites?

options.text: Web 2.0 requires more memory than Web 1.0

feedback.short: Not quite\! Memory requirements are technical specs, not the defining characteristic.
feedback.detailed: Memory usage is a technical consideration but not the fundamental difference between Web 1.0 and 2.0. The key distinction is interactivity - Web 2.0 enabled users to create, share, and interact with content.
feedback.socraticHint: Whats the main difference between reading a newspaper online vs. posting on social media?

questions.correctAnswerText: Web 2.0 allows users to both read and write/interact, not just read-only

questions.prompt: You want to create a website that works well on phones, tablets, and computers. What should you prioritize?

options.text: Using only desktop-sized images

feedback.short: Not quite\! Desktop-only images wont work well on smaller mobile screens.
feedback.detailed: Using only desktop-sized images would create problems on mobile devices - theyd be too large, slow to load, and difficult to view. Responsive design adapts content to different screen sizes.
feedback.socraticHint: What happens when you try to view a huge desktop image on a phone screen?

options.text: Responsive design and mobile-first approach
Creating separate websites for each device

feedback.short: Not quite\! Separate websites would be inefficient and hard to maintain.
feedback.detailed: Creating separate websites for each device type would triple your work and make updates difficult. Responsive design allows one website to adapt to all screen sizes automatically.
feedback.socraticHint: Is there a way to make one website that automatically adjusts to different screens?

options.text: Using only text content

feedback.short: Not quite\! Text-only content would sacrifice user experience and visual design.
feedback.detailed: While text-only sites are simple, they provide a poor user experience and dont solve the responsive design challenge. The goal is to make rich, visual content work across all devices.
feedback.socraticHint: How can you make images, videos, and styled content work on all device sizes?

questions.correctAnswerText: Responsive design and mobile-first approach

questions.prompt: Which of the following is the best example of a Web 2.0 website?

options.text: A company's static information page

feedback.short: Not quite\! Static information pages are characteristic of Web 1.0, not 2.0.
feedback.detailed: A static company information page is read-only content, which is typical of Web 1.0. Web 2.0 sites emphasize user interaction, content creation, and social features.
feedback.socraticHint: Can users interact with and create content on a static information page?

options.text: An online newspaper from 1995

feedback.short: Not quite\! Online newspapers from 1995 are Web 1.0 examples.
feedback.detailed: Newspapers from 1995 were read-only publications online - classic Web 1.0. Web 2.0 emerged in the 2000s with features like comments, sharing, and user-generated content.
feedback.socraticHint: Could 1995 newspaper readers comment, share, or create their own content?

options.text: Facebook with user-generated content and interaction
A simple text-only website

feedback.short: Not quite\! Simple text-only sites are Web 1.0 characteristics.
feedback.detailed: Text-only websites are typical of early Web 1.0 sites. Web 2.0 is defined by interactivity and user participation, not visual complexity.
feedback.socraticHint: What makes a website Web 2.0 - its appearance or how users can interact with it?

questions.correctAnswerText: Facebook with user-generated content and interaction

questions.prompt:
Why are both HTML and CSS important in web design?
---

options.text: HTML handles graphics while CSS handles text

feedback.short: Not quite\! HTML doesnt handle graphics, and CSS doesnt exclusively handle text.
feedback.detailed: Both HTML and CSS work together for all content types. HTML creates the structure and content (including text and images), while CSS styles everything visually.
feedback.socraticHint: Whats the difference between creating content and making it look good?

options.text: HTML creates structure/content while CSS creates style/design
HTML is for desktop while CSS is for mobile

feedback.short: Not quite\! HTML and CSS work together for all devices, not separately for desktop vs mobile.
feedback.detailed: HTML and CSS work together across all devices. The distinction isnt about device types but about function: HTML structures content, CSS styles it. Responsive design uses both for all devices.
feedback.socraticHint: Do you need different languages for desktop and mobile, or different approaches using the same languages?

options.text: HTML and CSS do the same thing

feedback.short: Not quite\! HTML and CSS serve different but complementary purposes.
feedback.detailed: HTML and CSS have distinct roles: HTML defines the structure and meaning of content, while CSS controls visual presentation. Separating these concerns makes websites easier to maintain and redesign.
feedback.socraticHint: Whats the difference between the content of a page and how it looks?

questions.correctAnswerText: HTML creates structure/content while CSS creates style/design

questions.prompt: What are the three main functions of HTML in web development?

options.text: Shows content, formats content, and creates links
Creates databases, manages servers, and handles security

feedback.short: Not quite\! Databases, servers, and security are backend concerns, not HTML functions.
feedback.detailed: HTML is a frontend language for creating web page structure and content. Backend technologies like databases and servers handle data storage and business logic.
feedback.socraticHint: Does HTML work in the users browser or on a remote server?

options.text: Designs graphics, edits photos, and creates animations

feedback.short: Not quite\! Graphics and photo editing are done with different tools, not HTML.
feedback.detailed: HTML displays images and content but doesnt create or edit graphics. Design software like Photoshop creates graphics, while HTML embeds them in web pages.
feedback.socraticHint: Can HTML create an image file, or can it only display one that already exists?

options.text: Writes code, tests programs, and fixes bugs

feedback.short: Not quite\! Writing, testing, and debugging apply to programming in general, not HTMLs specific purpose.
feedback.detailed: While developers do write and test HTML code, these are general programming activities. The question asks about HTMLs specific functions in web development: structuring content, formatting it, and creating links.
feedback.socraticHint: What specific things does HTML code accomplish on a webpage?

questions.correctAnswerText: Shows content, formats content, and creates links

questions.prompt: In the HTML "human body" analogy, what does the `<head>` section contain?

options.text: The visible content that users see

feedback.short: Not quite\! Visible content goes in the <body>, not the <head>.
feedback.detailed: The <head> section contains metadata - information about the page that browsers and search engines need but users dont see. Visible content like text and images goes in the <body> section.
feedback.socraticHint: If you want users to see something on the page, does it go in <head> or <body>?

options.text: Information about the page like the title
The navigation menu

feedback.short: Not quite\! Navigation menus are visible content, so they belong in the <body>.
feedback.detailed: Navigation menus are part of the visible page content. The <head> contains invisible metadata like the page title (shown in browser tab), character encoding, and linked stylesheets.
feedback.socraticHint: Can users see a navigation menu? If yes, which section should it go in?

options.text: The footer content

feedback.short: Not quite\! Footer content is visible on the page, so it goes in the <body>.
feedback.detailed: Footers are visible page elements that belong in the <body>. The <head> contains metadata like the document title, character set, and links to external resources.
feedback.socraticHint: Think about the human body analogy - what kind of information does your head contain?

questions.correctAnswerText: Information about the page like the title

questions.prompt: What happens when someone types a website address into their browser?

options.text: The computer automatically creates the webpage

feedback.short: Not quite\! The browser doesnt create the webpage - it requests and displays it.
feedback.detailed: When you type a URL, the browser sends a request to a web server. The server sends back HTML files, and the browser interprets and displays them. The webpage is created by developers, not generated automatically.
feedback.socraticHint: Where does the HTML code come from - the browser or a server?

options.text: Browser asks server for page, server sends HTML file, browser displays it
The website downloads permanently to the computer

feedback.short: Not quite\! Websites dont download permanently - theyre loaded temporarily.
feedback.detailed: When you visit a website, the browser temporarily downloads and displays the HTML. Its stored in cache for speed but not permanently. Each visit may fetch updated content from the server.
feedback.socraticHint: When you visit a website, does it stay on your computer forever or just while youre viewing it?

options.text: The browser connects directly to other users

feedback.short: Not quite\! Browsers connect to servers, not directly to other users.
feedback.detailed: Web browsing follows a client-server model: your browser (client) requests pages from web servers, which send back HTML files. The browser doesnt directly connect to other users.
feedback.socraticHint: When you visit a website, what computer sends you the webpage files?

questions.correctAnswerText: Browser asks server for page, server sends HTML file, browser displays it

questions.prompt:
Why does HTML use tags with angle brackets (< >) instead of regular text?
---

options.text: To make the code look more professional

feedback.short: Not quite\! Angle brackets arent about appearance - they serve a functional purpose.
feedback.detailed: Angle brackets create a clear syntax distinction. They tell the browser this is a command/instruction versus this is content to display. Without this distinction, browsers couldnt tell commands from text.
feedback.socraticHint: How does the browser know the difference between text to show users and instructions to follow?

options.text: To distinguish between content and instructions to the browser
Because angle brackets are easier to type

feedback.short: Not quite\! Angle brackets werent chosen for typing convenience.
feedback.detailed: The angle bracket syntax was designed for clarity and parsing, not ease of typing. It provides a clear visual and programmatic way to distinguish HTML instructions from page content.
feedback.socraticHint: Whats more important - easy typing or clear distinction between code and content?

options.text: To make the file size smaller

feedback.short: Not quite\! Angle brackets dont affect file size.
feedback.detailed: File size is determined by content length, not the characters used. Angle brackets were chosen to create clear syntax that distinguishes HTML tags from regular text content.
feedback.socraticHint: Would using different characters really change how much storage an HTML file needs?

questions.correctAnswerText: To distinguish between content and instructions to the browser

questions.prompt: What does CSS stand for and what is its primary purpose?

options.text: Computer Style System - manages computer settings

feedback.short: Not quite\! CSS doesnt manage computer settings - it styles websites.
feedback.detailed: CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) is a language specifically for styling web pages, not managing computer settings. It controls visual presentation like colors, fonts, layouts, and spacing.
feedback.socraticHint: What does Cascading Style Sheets suggest about CSSs purpose?

options.text: Cascading Style Sheets - controls how websites look
Creative Software Solutions - creates graphics

feedback.short: Not quite\! CSS doesnt create graphics - it styles existing content.
feedback.detailed: CSS styles and arranges content but doesnt create graphics from scratch. Graphics are created in design software and then styled/positioned with CSS on web pages.
feedback.socraticHint: Does CSS make images, or does it control how images look and where they appear?

options.text: Common Syntax Standards - standardizes code

feedback.short: Not quite\! CSS doesnt standardize code - it controls visual styling.
feedback.detailed: While CSS syntax has standards, CSSs purpose isnt to standardize code generally. Its specifically for controlling the visual presentation of web pages.
feedback.socraticHint: Think about what Style Sheets means - is it about code standards or visual appearance?

questions.correctAnswerText: Cascading Style Sheets - controls how websites look

questions.prompt: Which CSS method would be most efficient for styling a website with 10 pages?

options.text: Inline CSS - styles written directly in HTML elements

feedback.short: Not quite\! Inline CSS requires editing every single HTML element individually.
feedback.detailed: Inline CSS is the least efficient for multiple pages because youd need to edit styles on every element across all 10 pages. Any design change would require updating potentially hundreds of elements.
feedback.socraticHint: If you need to change button colors across 10 pages, do you want to edit 1 file or 100+ individual elements?

options.text: Internal CSS - styles written in each page's head section

feedback.short: Not quite\! Internal CSS means repeating the same styles in 10 different files.
feedback.detailed: Internal CSS lives in each pages <head> section. For 10 pages, youd duplicate the same styles 10 times. Changes require updating all 10 pages individually.
feedback.socraticHint: Would you rather maintain styles in 1 shared file or in 10 separate copies?

options.text: External CSS - one CSS file linked to all pages
No CSS - just use HTML for everything

feedback.short: Not quite\! Using only HTML means no styling capability and mixed content with presentation.
feedback.detailed: HTML without CSS provides no visual styling control and violates the separation of content (HTML) from presentation (CSS). Modern web development requires CSS for efficient, maintainable styling.
feedback.socraticHint: Can HTML alone control colors, fonts, and layouts like CSS can?

questions.correctAnswerText: External CSS - one CSS file linked to all pages

questions.prompt: You want to change the color of all headings from blue to green on a 10-page website. Which approach saves the most time?

options.text: Change each heading individually on every page

feedback.short: Not quite\! Changing each heading individually would take hours across 10 pages.
feedback.detailed: Editing each heading manually means finding and changing potentially dozens or hundreds of headings across all pages. This is time-consuming and error-prone.
feedback.socraticHint: Is there a way to change all headings at once with a single edit?

options.text: Use external CSS and change one file
Rewrite all the HTML code

feedback.short: Not quite\! Rewriting HTML doesnt change CSS styling.
feedback.detailed: The HTML content doesnt need to change - only the styling does. Rewriting HTML would be unnecessary work and wouldnt solve the color change problem.
feedback.socraticHint: Do you need to change the content (HTML) or just how it looks (CSS)?

options.text: Create a completely new website

feedback.short: Not quite\! Creating a new website is extremely wasteful for a simple color change.
feedback.detailed: This would be the most time-consuming approach imaginable. External CSS allows changing all heading colors by editing a single line in one file - thats its power.
feedback.socraticHint: Could you change the color in just one place and have it apply everywhere?

questions.correctAnswerText: Use external CSS and change one file

questions.prompt: For a blog post design, which CSS properties would be most appropriate for the author name?

options.text: Large font-size and bold font-weight

feedback.short: Not quite\! Large font and bold weight might overpower the blog post content.
feedback.detailed: Author names are typically secondary information that should be subtle, not prominent. Large, bold text would compete with the main content. Smaller, italic text provides appropriate visual hierarchy.
feedback.socraticHint: Should the author name stand out more than the blog post title and content?

options.text: Font-style italic and smaller font-size
Bright colors and blinking text

feedback.short: Not quite\! Bright colors and blinking text create visual distraction and poor UX.
feedback.detailed: Blinking text is considered bad web design practice - its distracting and can be accessibility issues. Author names should be subtle and readable, not attention-grabbing.
feedback.socraticHint: What creates a professional, readable blog post design?

options.text: Very large margins and padding

feedback.short: Not quite\! Large margins and padding would create excessive white space.
feedback.detailed: Very large margins and padding would push content apart and waste screen space. Author names need appropriate spacing but shouldnt dominate the layout.
feedback.socraticHint: Should author information take up more space than the blog content itself?

questions.correctAnswerText: Font-style italic and smaller font-size

questions.prompt:
How does separating HTML (content) from CSS (style) benefit web development?
---

options.text: It makes websites load faster

feedback.short: Not quite\! Load speed benefits are minor - the main advantage is maintainability.
feedback.detailed: While external CSS can be cached, speed isnt the primary benefit of separation. The key advantage is maintainability: you can redesign a site by editing CSS without touching HTML structure.
feedback.socraticHint: What happens when you need to redesign your sites look - is it easier with mixed or separated code?

options.text: It allows easier maintenance and design changes
It reduces the amount of code needed

feedback.short: Not quite\! Separation doesnt necessarily reduce code - it organizes it better.
feedback.detailed: Separating HTML and CSS might actually increase total code slightly, but thats not the point. The benefit is organization: content specialists can work on HTML while designers work on CSS independently.
feedback.socraticHint: Is less code always better, or is well-organized code more important?

options.text: It makes websites more secure

feedback.short: Not quite\! Security comes from backend practices, not HTML/CSS separation.
feedback.detailed: HTML and CSS are both frontend technologies and dont directly impact security. Security depends on backend code, server configuration, and data validation practices.
feedback.socraticHint: Do HTML structure and visual styling affect how hackers might attack a website?

questions.correctAnswerText: It allows easier maintenance and design changes

questions.prompt: What is the difference between class selectors and ID selectors in CSS?

options.text: Class selectors use (#) and ID selectors use (.)

feedback.short: Not quite\! You have the symbols backwards - classes use (.) and IDs use (#).
feedback.detailed: In CSS, class selectors start with a dot (.) like .button, and ID selectors start with a hash (#) like #header. This is a common mix-up to watch out for.
feedback.socraticHint: Which symbol do you see more often in CSS - the dot or the hashtag?

options.text: Class selectors use (.) and target multiple elements, ID selectors use (#) for unique elements
There is no difference between them

feedback.short: Not quite\! Classes and IDs have important differences in reusability and specificity.
feedback.detailed: Classes can be used on multiple elements and are less specific, while IDs should be unique per page and are more specific. This affects both your HTML structure and CSS cascade behavior.
feedback.socraticHint: Can you use the same ID on multiple elements, or should each ID be unique?

options.text: Class selectors are faster than ID selectors

feedback.short: Not quite\! Performance difference is negligible - the real difference is semantic and structural.
feedback.detailed: Classes and IDs have nearly identical performance. The important differences are about code organization: IDs for unique elements, classes for reusable styles.
feedback.socraticHint: Is the main reason to choose between class and ID about speed or about code structure?

questions.correctAnswerText: Class selectors use (.) and target multiple elements, ID selectors use (#) for unique elements

questions.prompt: What will the CSS selector `p.intro` target?

options.text: All paragraph elements

feedback.short: Not quite\! The (.) indicates this targets a specific class, not all paragraphs.
feedback.detailed: The selector `p.intro` combines an element selector (p) with a class selector (.intro), targeting only paragraphs that have class=intro. Just `p` would target all paragraphs.
feedback.socraticHint: What does the dot (.) in the selector tell you about which elements will be targeted?

options.text: All elements with class "intro"

feedback.short:
Not quite\! This selector is more specific - it requires both a

element AND the intro class.
feedback.detailed: The selector `p.intro` is more specific than just `.intro`. It only matches paragraph elements with the intro class, not divs or other elements with that class.
feedback.socraticHint:
Would
match this selector, or does it need to be a

tag?

options.text: Only paragraph elements with class "intro"
The element with ID "intro"

feedback.short: Not quite\! The (#) symbol selects IDs, but this selector uses (.) for classes.
feedback.detailed:
This selector uses a dot (.), which indicates a class, not a hash (#), which would indicate an ID. It targets elements like

, not

.
feedback.socraticHint: Whats the difference between a dot (.) and a hash (#) in CSS selectors?

questions.correctAnswerText: Only paragraph elements with class "intro"

questions.prompt: For a navigation menu where all links are blue but the current page link should be red and bold, what CSS approach would you use?

options.text: Use only element selectors for all links

feedback.short: Not quite\! Element selectors alone cant distinguish the current page from other links.
feedback.detailed: Element selectors like `a` apply to all links equally. You need a way to specifically target the current page link differently, which requires a class or ID.
feedback.socraticHint: If all links use the same element selector, how can you make one link look different?

options.text: Use class selectors for all links, plus a special class for the current page
Use only inline styles

feedback.short: Not quite\! Inline styles work but violate the separation of content and presentation.
feedback.detailed: While inline styles would work technically, they mix styling into HTML and make maintenance difficult. Using classes in external CSS is more maintainable and follows best practices.
feedback.socraticHint: Is there a way to style different links differently while keeping CSS separate from HTML?

options.text: Use different HTML elements instead

feedback.short: Not quite\! HTML elements define content structure, not visual styling.
feedback.detailed: All navigation links should use <a> elements regardless of styling. CSS classes are the proper way to apply different visual styles to the same type of HTML element.
feedback.socraticHint: Should you choose HTML elements based on content meaning or visual appearance?

questions.correctAnswerText: Use class selectors for all links, plus a special class for the current page

questions.prompt: For styling a contact form, which combination of selectors would be most organized?

options.text: Only element selectors for everything

feedback.short: Not quite\! Element selectors alone dont provide enough flexibility for different field types.
feedback.detailed: Using only element selectors means all inputs, all labels, etc. would look identical. Forms need different styling for text inputs vs checkboxes vs buttons, which requires classes or IDs.
feedback.socraticHint: Can you style text inputs differently from checkboxes if both use only element selectors?

options.text: Element selectors for general form styling, class selectors for field types, ID for unique elements
Only class selectors for everything

feedback.short: Not quite\! Using only classes means missing out on element selectors for common styling.
feedback.detailed: Using only classes would mean creating unnecessary classes for everything, even when elements share common styles. A combination approach is more efficient and maintainable.
feedback.socraticHint: Do all form inputs share some common styling that you could apply with element selectors?

options.text: Only inline styles for each element

feedback.short: Not quite\! Inline styles create maintenance nightmares and violate best practices.
feedback.detailed: Inline styles would require editing HTML for every style change and make the markup cluttered and hard to read. External CSS with a selector strategy is far more maintainable.
feedback.socraticHint: If you need to change button colors across the form, would you rather edit CSS once or edit every buttons HTML?

questions.correctAnswerText: Element selectors for general form styling, class selectors for field types, ID for unique elements

questions.prompt:
Why does CSS provide multiple types of selectors instead of just one?
---

options.text: To make CSS more complicated

feedback.short: Not quite\! Multiple selector types reduce complexity by providing appropriate tools.
feedback.detailed: Multiple selector types (element, class, ID) actually simplify CSS by letting you choose the right level of specificity. Element selectors for broad styling, classes for reusable patterns, IDs for unique elements.
feedback.socraticHint: Do more tools always mean more complexity, or can the right tools make work easier?

options.text: To provide flexibility, reusability, and precise control
To slow down website loading

feedback.short: Not quite\! CSS selectors dont affect loading speed significantly.
feedback.detailed: The type of selector has minimal impact on loading speed. Different selectors exist to give developers precise control over styling specificity and reusability.
feedback.socraticHint: Are CSS features usually about performance or about giving developers better control?

options.text: To confuse beginners

feedback.short: Not quite\! CSS features are designed to help developers, not hinder them.
feedback.detailed: Multiple selector types exist to provide flexibility for different use cases: element selectors for global styles, classes for reusable patterns, IDs for unique elements. Each serves a purpose.
feedback.socraticHint: Would a language designed for developers intentionally include features to confuse them?

questions.correctAnswerText: To provide flexibility, reusability, and precise control

questions.prompt: What is the main purpose of the HTML `<div>` element?

options.text: To display images and videos

feedback.short:
Not quite\!
doesnt display media - elements like and
feedback.detailed: While divs can contain images and videos, the <div> element itself doesnt display media. Its purpose is to group and organize elements so CSS can style and position them.
feedback.socraticHint: Whats the difference between containing elements and displaying them?

options.text: To create forms and input fields

feedback.short: Not quite\! Forms use specific elements like <form>, <input>, and <button>, not <div>.
feedback.detailed: Forms are created with semantic elements like <form>, <input>, and <label>. Divs are often used to organize and layout form elements, but dont create forms themselves.
feedback.socraticHint: Does <div> create interactive form fields, or does it just help organize them?

options.text: To group other HTML elements for styling and layout
To add navigation menus

feedback.short: Not quite\! Navigation menus use <nav> and <a> elements, though divs may help organize them.
feedback.detailed: While divs can help structure navigation menus, the semantic <nav> element and <a> links are what create navigation. Divs provide grouping for styling and layout.
feedback.socraticHint: Does <div> create clickable links, or does it just help organize elements that do?

questions.correctAnswerText: To group other HTML elements for styling and layout

questions.prompt:
In this HTML structure, what is the purpose of the div with class "container"? ```html

My Website

```

options.text: To display the website title

feedback.short: Not quite\! The <h1> displays the title; the container div wraps other elements.
feedback.detailed: The <h1> element actually displays the title My Website. The container div wraps both the header div and the h1, providing a way to apply CSS styling and layout to the group.
feedback.socraticHint: Whats the difference between displaying content and organizing content?

options.text: To wrap and organize other elements for styling
To create a navigation menu

feedback.short: Not quite\! Navigation uses <nav> and <a> elements, not generic divs.
feedback.detailed: This code doesnt create navigation - its a container div wrapping a header section. Navigation menus would use <nav> elements with <a> links inside.
feedback.socraticHint: Does this code contain any <nav> or <a> elements that would create navigation?

options.text: To add images to the page

feedback.short: Not quite\! Images use elements, not divs.
feedback.detailed: Divs dont add images to pages - elements do that. The container div here provides structure and styling opportunities for the header content.
feedback.socraticHint: Does this code contain an tag, or just organizational divs?

questions.correctAnswerText: To wrap and organize other elements for styling

questions.prompt: To create a webpage layout with a sidebar and main content area side by side, what would you need?

options.text: Two separate HTML pages

feedback.short: Not quite\! One website with responsive layout is more efficient than separate pages.
feedback.detailed: Separate HTML pages would duplicate all your content and require maintaining two codebases. Using divs with CSS layout (flexbox or grid) creates one responsive site that works for both.
feedback.socraticHint: Can CSS make elements appear side-by-side on one page?

options.text: A container div with two child divs for sidebar and main content
Only CSS without any divs

feedback.short: Not quite\! CSS needs HTML structure to work with - it cant create layout from nothing.
feedback.detailed: CSS layouts like flexbox and grid need HTML structure to arrange. The divs provide the structure (sidebar and main content), while CSS positions them side by side.
feedback.socraticHint: What HTML elements would CSS target to create a two-column layout?

options.text: Multiple navigation menus

feedback.short: Not quite\! Navigation menus are for site links, not page layout structure.
feedback.detailed: Navigation menus help users move between pages but dont create page layouts. A sidebar/main content layout requires container divs positioned with CSS.
feedback.socraticHint: Do navigation menus create page layouts, or just help users navigate?

questions.correctAnswerText: A container div with two child divs for sidebar and main content

questions.prompt: For a blog post layout including title, author info, date, content, and tags, how would you structure it with divs?

options.text: Put everything in one div without organization

feedback.short: Not quite\! Unorganized content is hard to style and maintain.
feedback.detailed: Putting everything in one div without structure makes it difficult to style different sections differently. Grouping related elements (like author and date together) makes the code more maintainable and flexible.
feedback.socraticHint: Would it be easier to style elements that are logically grouped or all mixed together?

options.text: Group related elements logically (author + date in "post-meta" div, etc.)
Use only headings and paragraphs

feedback.short: Not quite\! Headings and paragraphs need divs for proper layout and grouping.
feedback.detailed: While headings and paragraphs provide semantic structure, divs are needed to group related elements (like author + date) and create layout sections that CSS can style as units.
feedback.socraticHint: How would you style the author and date together as a unit without a wrapper div?

options.text: Create separate pages for each section

feedback.short: Not quite\! Separate pages fragment the content - divs organize it on one page.
feedback.detailed: Creating separate pages would break up the natural flow of a blog post. Divs allow you to organize all sections on one page with different styling for each logical group.
feedback.socraticHint: Should a single blog post be split across multiple pages, or organized as sections on one page?

questions.correctAnswerText: Group related elements logically (author + date in "post-meta" div, etc.)

questions.prompt:
How do divs help with the relationship between HTML structure and CSS styling?
---

options.text: Divs replace the need for CSS

feedback.short: Not quite\! Divs work with CSS - they dont replace it.
feedback.detailed: Divs and CSS work together: divs create invisible containers that CSS can target for styling and layout. Divs without CSS would have no visual impact.
feedback.socraticHint: Can divs apply colors, fonts, or layouts without CSS?

options.text: Divs provide invisible containers that CSS can target for layout and design
Divs automatically style themselves

feedback.short: Not quite\! Divs need CSS to be styled - they dont have built-in styling.
feedback.detailed: Divs are semantic-free containers with no default styling. Theyre specifically designed to be styled by CSS. Without CSS, divs do nothing visible.
feedback.socraticHint: What happens if you add a <div> with no CSS - does it look different?

options.text: Divs only work with JavaScript

feedback.short: Not quite\! Divs are HTML elements, not JavaScript constructs.
feedback.detailed: Divs are HTML elements that work with CSS for layout and styling. While JavaScript can manipulate divs, their primary purpose is providing structure for CSS styling.
feedback.socraticHint: Do you need JavaScript to use divs for layout, or just HTML and CSS?

questions.correctAnswerText: Divs provide invisible containers that CSS can target for layout and design

questions.prompt: What problems does CSS Grid solve compared to traditional layout methods?

options.text: It makes text bigger and images smaller

feedback.short: Not quite\! CSS Grid is about layout, not content sizing.
feedback.detailed: CSS Grid doesnt change text or image sizes - it arranges elements in layouts. Grid solves layout challenges like creating complex multi-column/row designs that were difficult with older CSS techniques.
feedback.socraticHint: Is CSS Grid about changing content size or about arranging content in layouts?

options.text: It handles complex layouts, vertical centering, and responsive design easily
It automatically creates content for websites

feedback.short: Not quite\! CSS Grid is a layout tool, not a content generation tool.
feedback.detailed: CSS Grid arranges existing content but doesnt create content automatically. Content creation is done with HTML or server-side technologies, not CSS layout systems.
feedback.socraticHint: Does CSS create content, or does it just control how content looks and is arranged?

options.text: It makes websites load faster

feedback.short: Not quite\! Grid improves layout capability, not loading performance.
feedback.detailed: CSS Grid doesnt make sites load faster - it makes complex layouts easier to create and maintain. The benefits are in development efficiency and layout flexibility.
feedback.socraticHint: Is CSS Grid about improving developer experience or page load speed?

questions.correctAnswerText: It handles complex layouts, vertical centering, and responsive design easily

options.text: One column with three rows

feedback.short: Not quite\! The code defines columns, not rows.
feedback.detailed: The grid-template-columns property creates columns (vertical divisions). This code creates three columns with specific width ratios. For rows, youd use grid-template-rows.
feedback.socraticHint: What does grid-template-columns tell you about the layout direction?

options.text: Three columns with 1:2:1 ratio and 20px spacing
Two columns with equal width

feedback.short: Not quite\! The code specifies three columns (1fr 2fr 1fr), not two.
feedback.detailed: The grid-template-columns value lists three widths: 1fr, 2fr, and 1fr. Each value creates one column. Two columns would only have two values.
feedback.socraticHint: How many numbers are in grid-template-columns: 1fr 2fr 1fr?

options.text: A flexible layout that changes randomly

feedback.short: Not quite\! Grid creates predictable, defined layouts, not random ones.
feedback.detailed: CSS Grid creates precise, controlled layouts based on your specifications. The fr unit creates fractional widths (1:2:1 ratio here), which are flexible but predictable, not random.
feedback.socraticHint: Does 1fr 2fr 1fr create a random layout or a specific ratio?

questions.correctAnswerText: Three columns with 1:2:1 ratio and 20px spacing

questions.prompt: For a responsive layout showing 3 columns on desktop, 2 on tablet, and 1 on mobile, what CSS Grid approach would you use?

options.text: Create three separate websites

feedback.short: Not quite\! Three separate websites would triple the maintenance work.
feedback.detailed: Creating separate websites for each device would mean maintaining three codebases. Responsive design with media queries allows one website to adapt to all screen sizes automatically.
feedback.socraticHint: Is there a way to make one website adapt to different screens instead of building three?

options.text: Use media queries to change grid-template-columns for different screen sizes
Use only CSS without Grid

feedback.short: Not quite\! CSS without Grid doesnt solve the responsive layout challenge as elegantly.
feedback.detailed: You could use CSS without Grid (like floats or flexbox), but Grid with media queries provides the most straightforward solution for this specific requirement of changing column counts.
feedback.socraticHint: Which CSS feature is specifically designed for two-dimensional layouts with rows and columns?

options.text: Let users choose their preferred layout

feedback.short: Not quite\! Users shouldnt have to choose layouts - responsive design handles it automatically.
feedback.detailed: Good web design adapts automatically to screen size without requiring user intervention. Media queries detect screen size and apply appropriate layouts automatically.
feedback.socraticHint: Should websites adapt automatically to devices, or should users have to configure layouts?

questions.correctAnswerText: Use media queries to change grid-template-columns for different screen sizes

questions.prompt: For a photo gallery webpage with header, sidebar, main gallery, and footer, what CSS Grid structure would work best?

options.text: Put everything in a single row

feedback.short: Not quite\! Putting everything in one row wouldnt separate header, sidebar, gallery, and footer.
feedback.detailed: A photo gallery layout needs distinct areas for different content types. A single row cant create the necessary structure for header across the top, sidebar beside content, and footer at bottom.
feedback.socraticHint: Does a photo gallery need content arranged in both rows AND columns?

options.text: Use grid-template-areas or define columns/rows for each section
Use only flexbox instead

feedback.short: Not quite\! Flexbox is one-dimensional; this layout needs two-dimensional grid.
feedback.detailed: While flexbox works well for one-dimensional layouts (single row or column), a photo gallery with header, sidebar, main area, and footer needs two-dimensional control that Grid provides better.
feedback.socraticHint: Does this layout need to control both rows and columns simultaneously?

options.text: Create separate pages for each section

feedback.short: Not quite\! Separate pages would fragment what should be one cohesive gallery.
feedback.detailed: A photo gallery should be one integrated page with header, navigation (sidebar), photos, and footer all visible together. Separate pages would break the user experience.
feedback.socraticHint: Should a photo gallery be one unified layout or split across multiple pages?

questions.correctAnswerText: Use grid-template-areas or define columns/rows for each section

questions.prompt:
How does CSS Grid change your approach to thinking about web page layouts?
---

options.text: It makes you avoid using layout altogether

feedback.short: Not quite\! Grid enables layouts, it doesnt discourage them.
feedback.detailed: CSS Grid actually encourages better layouts by making them easier to implement. It enables grid-based thinking where you plan content in rows and columns.
feedback.socraticHint: Does a tool that makes layouts easier encourage you to use layouts more or less?

options.text: It enables grid-based thinking and simplifies complex layouts
It requires more complex code than before

feedback.short: Not quite\! Grid simplifies complex layouts compared to older methods.
feedback.detailed: CSS Grid actually reduces code complexity compared to float-based or table-based layouts. It provides intuitive syntax for creating complex layouts that previously required complicated workarounds.
feedback.socraticHint: Does Grid make complex layouts easier or harder to code than old methods like floats?

options.text: It only works for simple layouts

feedback.short: Not quite\! Grid excels at complex layouts - its overkill for simple ones.
feedback.detailed: CSS Grid is specifically designed for complex, two-dimensional layouts. For simple layouts, flexbox or even basic CSS might be simpler. Grids power is in handling complexity easily.
feedback.socraticHint: When would you need a two-dimensional grid layout - for simple or complex designs?

questions.correctAnswerText: It enables grid-based thinking and simplifies complex layouts

questions.prompt: What is a CSS framework and why do developers use them?

options.text: A tool for writing HTML faster

feedback.short: Not quite\! CSS frameworks are for styling, not HTML creation.
feedback.detailed: CSS frameworks provide pre-written CSS styles and components, not HTML shortcuts. They help you style faster, but you still write HTML as usual.
feedback.socraticHint: Does CSS framework suggest it helps with CSS or HTML?

options.text: Pre-written CSS that provides common styling patterns and speeds up development
A way to avoid learning CSS completely

feedback.short: Not quite\! Frameworks help you learn CSS efficiently, not avoid learning it.
feedback.detailed: Using frameworks requires understanding CSS to customize and override framework styles. Theyre tools to speed up development once you know CSS, not replacements for CSS knowledge.
feedback.socraticHint: Can you effectively use a CSS framework without understanding how CSS works?

options.text: Software for designing graphics

feedback.short: Not quite\! CSS frameworks are code libraries, not graphics software.
feedback.detailed: CSS frameworks are collections of pre-written CSS code, not design tools. Graphics design uses software like Figma or Photoshop, while CSS frameworks help implement designs in code.
feedback.socraticHint: Is a CSS framework a design tool or a development tool?

questions.correctAnswerText: Pre-written CSS that provides common styling patterns and speeds up development

questions.prompt: What are the main trade-offs between custom CSS and CSS frameworks?

options.text: Custom CSS is always better than frameworks

feedback.short: Not quite\! Neither approach is universally better - each has appropriate use cases.
feedback.detailed: Custom CSS gives complete control and unique designs but takes more time. Frameworks speed development but may make sites look similar. The right choice depends on project needs: timeline, budget, uniqueness requirements.
feedback.socraticHint: Do different projects have different priorities for speed vs uniqueness?

options.text: Custom CSS gives complete control but takes more time; frameworks are faster but less unique
Frameworks are always better than custom CSS

feedback.short: Not quite\! Frameworks arent always better - they trade uniqueness for speed.
feedback.detailed: Frameworks are faster but can make websites look generic if not customized. For highly unique, artistic designs, custom CSS often works better. The best choice depends on project requirements.
feedback.socraticHint: Would an artists portfolio site benefit more from unique custom CSS or a standard framework?

options.text: There are no differences between them

feedback.short: Not quite\! There are significant differences in development speed and design uniqueness.
feedback.detailed: Custom CSS and frameworks differ substantially: frameworks provide pre-built components for fast development but less uniqueness, while custom CSS offers complete control but requires more time.
feedback.socraticHint: Would building every button from scratch take the same time as using pre-made framework buttons?

questions.correctAnswerText: Custom CSS gives complete control but takes more time; frameworks are faster but less unique

questions.prompt: Your team has a tight deadline but your designer wants a very unique look that doesn't match framework styles. What approach would you recommend?

options.text: Use only custom CSS despite the deadline

feedback.short: Not quite\! Tight deadlines require balancing speed with quality requirements.
feedback.detailed: Using only custom CSS would miss the deadline. The better approach balances efficiency (framework for structure and common components) with customization (custom CSS for unique design elements).
feedback.socraticHint: Is there a way to get both speed AND uniqueness by combining approaches?

options.text: Start with a framework for structure, then customize unique elements
Ignore the designer's requirements

feedback.short: Not quite\! Ignoring requirements leads to poor outcomes and unhappy stakeholders.
feedback.detailed: Designers provide requirements for good reasons - unique design can be a competitive advantage. The right approach respects both the deadline and design requirements by using a hybrid strategy.
feedback.socraticHint: Can you meet both deadline and design needs by using a framework as a foundation?

options.text: Use only frameworks without customization

feedback.short: Not quite\! Frameworks without customization wont achieve the unique look required.
feedback.detailed: Using frameworks without customization would be fast but wouldnt meet the unique design requirement. The solution is to use frameworks for efficiency where possible while customizing unique elements.
feedback.socraticHint: Can you use a frameworks grid system but customize colors, fonts, and unique components?

questions.correctAnswerText: Start with a framework for structure, then customize unique elements

questions.prompt: Which types of projects would benefit most from using CSS frameworks?

options.text: Highly artistic and unique design websites

feedback.short: Not quite\! Artistic sites need unique designs, which frameworks can limit.
feedback.detailed: Highly artistic and unique design websites benefit most from custom CSS where designers have complete control. Frameworks can make sites look generic and limit creative expression.
feedback.socraticHint: Do frameworks help or hinder when you need a completely unique, artistic design?

options.text: Business websites, admin dashboards, and prototypes
Personal art portfolios

feedback.short: Not quite\! Art portfolios need unique designs that stand out from framework templates.
feedback.detailed: Personal art portfolios should showcase unique design skills and stand out from the crowd. Using popular frameworks might make them look like thousands of other sites.
feedback.socraticHint: Should an artists portfolio look unique or like a template?

options.text: Websites that need to load extremely fast

feedback.short: Not quite\! Frameworks can actually increase file size compared to minimal custom CSS.
feedback.detailed: Frameworks often include unused CSS, potentially making sites larger, not faster. Speed benefits come from CDN delivery and browser caching, but custom CSS can be more lightweight.
feedback.socraticHint: Does including a full framework with unused styles make files bigger or smaller?

questions.correctAnswerText: Business websites, admin dashboards, and prototypes

questions.prompt:
How do CSS frameworks change your perspective on development tool choices?
---

options.text: Frameworks are always the right choice

feedback.short: Not quite\! Frameworks arent universally right - the best choice depends on context.
feedback.detailed: CSS frameworks are one tool among many. The right choice depends on project requirements: timeline, budget, uniqueness needs, and team skills. Sometimes custom CSS is better.
feedback.socraticHint: Can you think of projects where custom CSS would serve better than a framework?

options.text: Development involves balancing efficiency with customization needs
Custom code is always superior

feedback.short: Not quite\! Custom code has advantages but isnt always superior.
feedback.detailed: Custom code provides complete control and uniqueness but takes more time. Frameworks trade some uniqueness for development speed. Neither is universally superior - it depends on project needs.
feedback.socraticHint: Is development speed ever more important than complete design control?

options.text: Tools don't matter in development

feedback.short: Not quite\! Tools significantly impact development efficiency and outcomes.
feedback.detailed: Development tools matter greatly. Choosing between frameworks and custom CSS affects development time, design uniqueness, maintenance effort, and final quality. Good developers choose appropriate tools for each project.

questions.prompt: What does "utility-first" mean in Tailwind CSS philosophy?

options.text: Using large pre-built components like Bootstrap

feedback.short: Not quite! Tailwind is utility-first, not component-based.
feedback.detailed: Tailwind provides low-level utility classes (like 'flex', 'p-4', 'text-center') that you combine to build custom designs. Component frameworks like Bootstrap provide pre-built components (buttons, navbars). Tailwind gives you building blocks instead of finished components.
feedback.socraticHint: What's the difference between getting pre-built furniture versus getting tools and materials to build your own?

options.text: Using many small, single-purpose classes to build custom designs
Writing all styles in separate CSS files

feedback.short: Not quite! Tailwind classes are different from inline styles.
feedback.detailed: While Tailwind classes apply styles directly in HTML, they're not inline styles. Tailwind generates optimized CSS classes that can be reused, support responsive design with breakpoints, and enable hover/focus statesnone of which inline styles can do efficiently.
feedback.socraticHint: Can inline styles respond to different screen sizes or hover states as easily as classes?

options.text: Avoiding CSS classes altogether

feedback.short: Not quite! Modern frameworks like Tailwind minimize overhead.
feedback.detailed: Tailwind uses a build process that removes unused CSS, keeping the final bundle small. Traditional frameworks ship all components whether you use them or not, but Tailwind only includes the utilities you actually use in your HTML.
feedback.socraticHint: What if a framework only shipped the code you actually use instead of everything it offers?

questions.correctAnswerText: Using many small, single-purpose classes to build custom designs
